question_list.author: MikeAq
question_list.text:
To compose a morose epicedium
Can brighten one's torpor and tedium.
I myself have an urge
To create a sad dirge —
One not overly mournful, just medium.
question_list.question: How can one brighten one's torpor and tedium?
alternate_answers:
The limerick suggests that composing a morose epicedium (a funeral song or poem) can help brighten one's torpor and tedium. The limerick states:

"To compose a morose epicedium 
Can brighten one's torpor and tedium.
I myself have an urge
To create a sad dirge —
One not overly mournful, just medium."

So the answer is that writing a moderately melancholy funeral poem or song can help alleviate boredom and listlessness, according to the limerick.

Compose a morose epicedium.
Craft a sad dirge, not too mournful,
Just medium, not scornful,
To lift your spirits, a musical medium.

question_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
question_list.text:
Our most serious faces we don
As the blamestorming session goes on.
Someone died. Who's to blame?
The one person we name
Is a janitor's helper named Juan.
question_list.question: Who do they blame in the blamestorming session after someone dies?
alternate_answers:
Based on the limericks, it seems the person they blame in the blamestorming session after someone dies is often a scapegoat or someone undeserving of the blame. 

For example, one limerick mentions:

"Someone died. Who's to blame?
The one person we name
Is a janitor's helper named Juan."

This suggests that in the blamestorming session, they unfairly blame an innocent person, like the janitor's helper Juan, rather than finding the true cause of the death.

question_list.author: proof
question_list.text:
Have a car and my clothes without fail
Outside of this old county jail.
It has only one fence,
 Which does not make much sense,
So tomorrow I'll scale it and bail.
question_list.question: what about the county jail does not make much sense?
alternate_answers: The limerick about the county jail mentions a person who plans to scale the fence to escape the jail, which is not a typical or sensible way to leave a jail.

Based on the limerick, the detail that does not make much sense about the county jail is that it "has only one fence". The limerick suggests this is odd, implying a typical county jail would have more than one fence to help secure the facility and prevent inmates from escaping.

question_list.author: Richard English
question_list.text:
Some folks might think cranberry glass
Is for fruit of the cranberry class.
But it's glass of deep red,
With a gold sheen, and said
To be sought by the English top brass.
question_list.question: What is sought by the English top brass?

question_list.author: MikeAq
question_list.text:
Mr. Thistle, what's this all about?
All our rules you dismiss — baldly flout.
I have read your epistle;
It made my hairs bristle.
I'm blowing the whistle — you're out!
question_list.question: Does Mr. Thistle follow our rules?
alternate_answers: Mr. Thistle does not follow the rules consistently. He often disregards them without explanation or justification.

Based on the limericks provided, the question appears to be about the limerick that mentions "Mr. Thistle". The relevant limerick is:

"Mr. Thistle, what's this all about? 
All our rules you dismiss — baldly flout.
I have read your epistle;
It made my hairs bristle.
I'm blowing the whistle — you're out!"

This limerick suggests that Mr. Thistle does not follow the rules, as the speaker is blowing the whistle on him for dismissing and flouting the rules.

question_list.author: Howard Spindel
question_list.text:
I've a tree in my yard in a plight;
All its leaves are diseased — it's a sight.
And the skin of that tree
Peels to such a degree
That its bark is much worse than its blight.
question_list.question: What is the plight of the tree in my yard?
alternate_answers: The tree in the yard has diseased leaves and peeling bark, which is a sight.

question_list.author: SheilaB
question_list.text:
Uncle Wayne always gives me a pain.
His ideas are vain and inane.
He's both asinine (fatuous)
And a gas bag who's flatuous.
I treat the old fool with disdain.
question_list.question: What is wrong with Uncle Wayne's ideas?
question_list.answer: Uncle Wayne's ideas are vain and inane.
alternate_answers:
Uncle Wayne's ideas are considered vain and inane,
He's both asinine and flatuous, causing disdain.

Based on the limerick, there are a few things wrong with Uncle Wayne's ideas:

1. They are described as "vain and inane" - meaning they are empty, worthless, and foolish.

2. He is characterized as being "asinine" - which means stupid or foolish. 

3. He is also described as being a "gas bag" who is "flatuous" - implying his ideas are full of hot air and empty rhetoric.

4. The narrator treats Uncle Wayne with "disdain" - showing a strong dislike and lack of respect for his ideas.

Overall, the limerick portrays Uncle Wayne's ideas as being foolish, stupid, and unworthy of serious consideration. The narrator clearly has a very negative view of his uncle's thought processes and opinions.

question_list.author: Joanna Keene
question_list.text:
Joey fingered Big Lou as the one
Who shot Johnny six times with his gun.
Snitched him out: "Louie did it;
The goon never hid it."
Now Joey lives life on the run.
question_list.question: Who did Joey finger for shooting Johnny?

question_list.author: Celia Warren
question_list.text:
Oh, don't throw your toys out your pram!
Yes, I treat all your emails as spam.
Hurt your feelings? Don't care;
I don't like you, so there!
Just accept that I don't give a damn!
question_list.question: Why do I treat all your emails as spam?
alternate_answers:
Because I don't like you, so there!
Your feelings? I don't really care.
Just accept that I'm cold,
And your messages, old,
Are as welcome as a grizzly bear.

question_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
question_list.text:
That damn call button jockey, room 9,
Is a pain in the base of my spine.
For no reason he rings
About minuscule things.
His sole purpose? To hear himself whine.
question_list.question: What is the sole purpose of the occupant of room 9?
alternate_answers: The sole purpose of the occupant of room 9 is to repeatedly press the call button, which can be quite frustrating for others.
The sole purpose of the occupant of room 9 is to ring the call button for no significant reason, mainly to hear himself whine.

limerick_list.author: Virge
limerick_list.text:
Yes, chocolate chip cookies are fun.
They're a snack food that can't be outdone.
But one batch won't suffice:
Up the quantities (thrice).
On your recipe scribble, "Serves one."

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
You should order the coeur à la crème—
It's their cream cheese and sour cream gem.
With fresh berries on top,
It's the pride of the shop.
Fussy folks say, "Too sweet," but that's them.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Johnny Mathis once sang something grand—
"There is one thing I can't understand:
Like a kitten that's treed,
I am helpless indeed.
I get brumous just holding your hand."

limerick_list.author: turnip
limerick_list.text:
Have more mu shu, my darling, 'fore bed.
I just need to make sure you're well-fed —
Else the cumulative poison
I've put in your hoisin
Won't build till the point that you're dead.

limerick_list.author: nevadaace and speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
My friend Sven said, "When men have a yen
For Norwegian books now and again,
Knowing Bokmål will do,
As will Nynorsk—those two
Are the dominant tongues in our ken."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
One day, as I walked through a bog,
I encountered a talkative frog.
"Were you changed by a curse?
Once a prince?" "No, it's worse!
I'm in love with a bump on a log!"

limerick_list.author: creelbm
limerick_list.text:
Chikako's planned birthday oration
Was marred by her mis-formulation
Of the right English sound.
What came out was profound:
"Thanks for coming to this cerebration."

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
I reckoned, as soon as I read it,
Your limerick required an edit.
The metre is wrong,
Half the lines are too long,
And the joke isn't strong. There, I said it.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
What is dapperness? Look at that rapper.
He wears more strings of bling than a flapper.
Pants are droopy and wide;
Cap is turned to the side,
But he's sure that he's stylish and dapper.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
My only concern's to protect ya weight
(You're obese). I know what (I have checked) you ate.
I've looked in ya larder —
It's bare. Please try harder.
(This rhyme's tough to produce: to effectuate).

limerick_list.author: Roger Vick and Chris Young
limerick_list.text:
An assimilator,  that's what I am:
Loads of data's absorbed as I cram.
Into textbooks I plunge
With a brain like a sponge —
Which I'll squeeze in my final exam.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Adenodynia's a word
For another word no one has heard.
You've a pain in a gland?
Just say that, understand?
Simple straightforward talk is preferred.

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
My new vitamin spray is inhalable,
But I fear it will fail to be salable.
The stuff's composition
Holds tons of nutrition—
Too bad it's not bioavailable.

limerick_list.author: Joanna Keene
limerick_list.text:
To a biker-bar brawl off Route 10
Came two brash but untested young men
Who engaged in the fray
In an educative way:
They learned not to do it again.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Vince was enervated, pooped, all worn out,
Though that term might appear to give doubt
To his state. True, it sounds
Like his oomph knows no bounds,
But that's not what this word is about.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
From the coffee pot's bottom this came.
It tastes horrible!  Dregs are to blame.
That's the grounds or the sediment—
Good coffee's impediment.
Society's dregs are the same.

limerick_list.author: Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
My stomach felt empty and hollow,
So my wife cooked me penne al pollo;
But I just couldn't eat.
What caused my defeat?
Aphagia — it means you can't swallow.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Being gullible, Steven gave credence
To predictions of Pete's supersedence
In the coming election,
So he made no objection
When he heard about voting impedance.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
When you know what you've done isn't right
And you've hurt someone's feelings, you might
Feel remorseful and sad
And regret acting bad.
If you do, then we say you're contrite.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
Freddie Mercury? He was Queen's front man
(Like Bill Haley, a singer, no stuntman).
Manfred Mann had Paul Jones,
Jagger's Mick "fronts" the Stones,
And each front man is often a blunt man.

limerick_list.author: Carol June Hooker
limerick_list.text:
One word means delight, and constrain,
Surprise, pity, threaten, complain.
"Say ah," my Doc said;
My jaw locked up instead:
I regret I'm "ah"stricken in pain.

limerick_list.author: Jacqui Brown
limerick_list.text:
Stay snug on your cradleboard, sleep,
My little one, slumbering deep.
Soon you'll run wild and free,
But for now ride with me,
And a vigilant watch I shall keep.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
"Persevere!" my old prof used to preach.
"Any prize you pursue's within reach!
Pull no punches, plunge in,
Pay the price and you'll win—
Though it won't be a day at the beach."

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
'But you said I could drink from a flagon
That hadn't been stamped with a dragon.'
'Yes—but, if you spot it,
Don't take a drink. Got it?'
'Yes, gotcha. I'll stay on the wagon.'

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In his caseload are several guys
Of the type that most folks would despise.
With his Yale education
He wins them probation
(From judges with Yale old school ties).

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My neighbor is so antigun
Any story with firearms he'll shun,
So he rants at TV,
And hates newspapers; he
As a friend isn't really much fun.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
I'll compare you to summer today.
You're both hotter (and cooler) I'd say,
And baby, the thing
Is you'll always have zing,
Whereas summer will soon fade away.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
I won't marry my sweetie, Maria Blee—
She'll be just like her mother, foreseeably,
Who is, sad to report,
Nasty, brutish, and short,
So our marriage could end disagreeably.

limerick_list.author: Comicoffee
limerick_list.text:
Pam Anderson's body is nice
With her cleavage enhanced (maybe twice?).
She's a big-bosomed broad,
So c'mon guys, applaud
For the human flotation device!

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
Hey, the circus is coming to town.
It's low-rated and lacking renown.
Their advance man makes plans
To bring out the fans,
Then performs every night as a clown.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In botanical studies, one learns
About flowers and mosses and ferns.
When one's  ageotropic,
It's not quite utopic—
Away from the earth, the plant turns.

limerick_list.author: Egbert
limerick_list.text:
This hombre's cool gaze knows no fear.
He lunges — a gasp, then a cheer.
Now el toro's just meat
And the crowd's on its feet
For the matador. And a loose ear.

limerick_list.author: Suzanne Kreul
limerick_list.text:
When the king says, "Oh please, do attend,"
Then you surely don't want to offend.
You had better be there,
Or you'd better beware
That you might lose your head in the end.

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
When in summer they come from their caves
To our beaches to savour the waves,
The surfers and shaggies
Clad only in baggies
Go battle the ocean like braves.

limerick_list.author: jayrusalem
limerick_list.text:
I'm no longer antipornographic,
Since this film starring Sarah Seraphic.
When she turns up the heat,
You should stay off the street,
For that body will really stop traffic.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
The Tsar needed cash, so he sold
The Yankees Alaska, we're told.
Though this Purchase (good golly!)
Was dubbed Seward's Folly
His action, let's face it, was bold.

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
Mix potatoes with flaked, salted cod,
And roll up into balls—but how odd
That the name of this dish
Could mean "dances for fish"
If they'd been so enabled by God.

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
Some hors d'oeuvres with a glass of Chablis?
Then we'll eat coq au vin, ma chérie.
And before le café
I shall serve crême brûlée.
So enjoy it all!  Bon appétit!

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
Football stadiums, as I recall,
Are spectacular, so they enthrall
Spectators: take Wembley,
Where a lively assembly
Of 22 men kick a ball.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The elephant (African bush)
Is the winner when shove comes to push
In most cases. Beware
If he's sitting. Take care
That you don't end up under his tush.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
My repair will be fully corrective;
Your leg will be strong, not defective.
My technique, diorthotic,
Is sound, not quixotic,
When applied with my expert perspective.

limerick_list.author: Brent Annable
limerick_list.text:
Your incredible lack of finesse
Has decidedly failed to impress.
I can see in your eyes
That you're selling me lies
And ebulliently talking BS.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
"We're in perfect agreeance"?  Good grief!
I, aggrieved, disagree.  What's my beef?
For achievement, achievance?
No! Here is my grievance:
Just say in agreement, please, chief.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
This gazebo I plan to festoon—
Drape with flowers—beneath the full moon.
There my sweetheart I'll meet,
And I'll kneel at her feet.
When I beg her to wed me, she'll swoon.

limerick_list.author: Harris Risman
limerick_list.text:
Chris Christie, who's plumper than plump,
Is derided by some as a chump
When this governor says,
"Vote for Donald as prez!"
Though Trump's trash talk belongs in the dump.

limerick_list.author: P Walowitz
limerick_list.text:
Grim Madame Defarge sat and knitted
Their names and the crimes they committed.
As a citizeness,
She cried, "Kill the noblesse!"
So their heads, one by one, were unfitted.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
What was Timothy Malley to do?
He was challenged, a brawl might ensue.
A fair fight he could win,
But his foe had a twin.
In a donnybrook, could Tim buck two?

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
"And excyst. Of this word, what's the gist?"
"To continue: this worm, to exist
In your gut (it's quite simple),
Escapes from its pimple
And feeds on you. Right? Class dismissed."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
What is bent? It is one kind of grass—
Narrow leaves, tender stems—but alas,
Call it dog bent or brown bent,
Its stems will be down bent
When we tromp on this grass as we pass.

limerick_list.author: Bit
limerick_list.text:
Making salt often starts with some brine
(Salty water) you boil, or you shine
Lots of sunlight upon
'Til the water's all gone
From the brine pan, where crystals combine.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
One subject I never can master:
At chemistry I'm a disaster.
I fail, so I'm critically,
Autocatalytically,
Breaking down faster and faster.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan and Mark Mironer
limerick_list.text:
Now our arrow of time is a curse
As entropic disorder gets worse.
You can talk of string theory,
But of wormholes I'm leery.
Even they can't make time's flow reverse!

limerick_list.author: Sussexdownsman
limerick_list.text:
Boating lights in the night, it is said,
Aid safe passing at sea; white, green, red.
Where together are seen,
Red to red, green to green,
Then it's perfectly safe. Go ahead.

However, the way one should steer,
Should to starboard a red light appear,
Is laid down as a fact;
It's one's duty to act
In whatever way keeps one well clear.

Off to port, if a green light should show,
As a skipper or helmsman you know
What that vessel must do;
It's keep well clear of you.
Hold your course is the right way to go.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
I am culturally broad in my style.
I wear Indian beads that beguile.
I sport fringed cowboy boots
And I don't give two hoots
If my lovely grass skirt makes you smile.

limerick_list.author: Dave Jermy
limerick_list.text:
Do I know every fielding position?
Well, there's slip, cover, point. In addition,
Mid on and mid off,
Plus the sillies. (Don't scoff!)
To explain them more clearly's my mission.

limerick_list.author: Len Farano
limerick_list.text:
Michael Faraday, scientist rare:
Little schooling but talent to spare.
He provided instruction
On magnetic induction,
Electrolysis, other such fare.

limerick_list.author: Howard Spindel and J. E. Pettit
limerick_list.text:
Let's begin at the end just for fun.
There's no style, there's no flair.
What a boring affair!
They always begin on line one.
This limerick has barely begun.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
"Ruben Rodkind —  it's not what you think,"
I told friends, when they asked with a wink.
"It's a screen name, okay?
That I made up one day —
It's my anagram (Bernd Udo Rink)".

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Budgie-smuggling, he shows off his pecs.
And for Lent he says, "I'll give up sex."
Abbott, T.,  look at me:
Have a nice cup of tea
And a lie-down (and, yes, take a Bex).

limerick_list.author: abbeycadabra
limerick_list.text:
When comparing the zenith-to-base
With the width of a skull, in this case
There's pronounced elongation —
As well, consternation
When people ask "Why the long face?"

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
She envisaged a colourful hall;
Now it's purple and gold on each wall,
Striped with aquamarine.
She imagines the scene
Next time mother-in-law pays a call!

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
At a circus most faces wore frowns,
Since there wasn't much joy on its grounds.
Seems the circus lacked funny —
It ran out of money.
To save cash, they defunded the clowns.

limerick_list.author: stella
limerick_list.text:
The cinereous vulture will soar
On great wings that can span a barn door.
It is carrion-fed,
With a featherless head
So it doesn't get splattered in gore.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Edwards syndrome: low birth weight, small head.
This Trisomy 18 is dread,
Causing gross malformation
And grave retardation;
Near all babes, by age one, sadly, dead.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"Baby-minder." The ad sounded fun.
"We will pay you to mind our young son."
On my very first try
I was fired, but why?
Each demand the kid made I had done.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
Once the capital cost has been met
For the premises, then the new vet
Can start fixing the ills
Of folks' pets. Settled bills
Will soon bring reimbursement, I bet.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
We've adopted a cat who's a cadger,
And brockfaced (with stripes like a badger).
She will tangle my yarn,
Then stalk owls in the barn.
If she gets one, I'm naming her Padger.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
A gasoline pumper am I.
"Fill 'er up!" is what customers cry.
I've filled thousands of tanks;
Though I rarely hear "Thanks!",
I'll a gas jockey be till I die.

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
The heist we were busily plotting.
Personnel into roles we were slotting—
This for him, that for you—
When asked what did I do,
I replied, "I'm the one who's allotting."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
To write limericks I have the ability,
And for humor a certain facility.
But a new OED
Even I plainly see
Is an exercise born of futility.

limerick_list.author: D F-B
limerick_list.text:
The Athenian court of appeal
Was itself a place hard to conceal,
Set on Ares's Hill.
Areopagite skill
Was to seek truths the gods might reveal.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A red pipe was severed on Brad.
The result is blood's spurting like mad.
When a blue pipe is cut,
That's still serious, but
Then the bleeding's not nearly so bad.

limerick_list.author: Colin Salter
limerick_list.text:
Look for Panda Hill, west Tanzania:
Mine your bariopyrochlore here.
It's niobium-rich
And has strontium, which
Make it worth digging up. Persevere!

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
If adventure to you often calls,
Then you might want to see Angel Falls.
For the ultimate peril,
Shoot these in a barrel!
To do so, you'd have to have nerve.

limerick_list.author: Shelby Forrest
limerick_list.text:
City slickers thought hicks could be beat
In a milking event. T'would be neat.
But one cocky young fool
Was kicked clear off  his stool
By a "cow" that had only one teat.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Coruscatingly witty, he shines;
On each topic he brightly opines.
He's so dazzlingly smart
That he's captured my heart...
(I've had nine of these blackberry wines.)

limerick_list.author: turnip and Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
I see colors, except for one hue,
With acyanopsia, true;
But my victory's pyrrhic
When singing the lyric:
"Hurrah for the red, white, and ... ummm...."

limerick_list.author: MattMonitto
limerick_list.text:
I thought, "Hurt? Not a chance." Not for long!
Now I'm shredded to bits; I was wrong.
Heed these words that I speak:
Don't play hide-and-go-seek
In a Christ's-thorn while wearing a thong.

limerick_list.author: Hfox
limerick_list.text:
It's true that we humans are flightless;
In darkness we're very near sightless.
But whatever we're missing,
We've got lips for kissing
To make the long night less delightless.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Burt Bacharach's fame is widespread;
"He's the tops of the pops," folks have said.
But the song they're recallin'
Is "Raindrops Keep Fallin'"
(I hate this song, Burt!) "On My Head."

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
"A hot water bottle, I thought,
Was the thing that you meant when you bought
A bed warmer," she said
When she found, in my bed,
A hooker, and got overwrought.

limerick_list.author: Jason Talbott
limerick_list.text:
His acrobatism wowed the whole crowd,
Made the calmest of men gasp out loud.
He was bold, he was daring.
Those tights he was wearing
Blew out in the end when he bowed.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In my bedroom, the paint seems to peel.
Flakes now cover my bed. What's the deal?
Guess it's not from the walls
That this pesky paint falls,
So I'll have to get someone to ceil.

limerick_list.author: Beverley Sharp
limerick_list.text:
Pricey wine would taste fine, I suspect,
But your Dom Perignon I reject.
"Drink cheap!" is my motto;
Act daffy!  Get blotto!
I call it "the Ripple effect."

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Here's to you, founding father. Well done.
You funded our firm from day one.
Our wealth, it was grounded
By you; and you founded
(By diddling me mum) me, your son.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
Consider the cyclograph's core bits:
Geared-wheels-within-rings-where-you-draw bits.
Kids' fad for shapes spiral
(Egad!) just went viral—
Pen flowers, for hours, in orbits.

limerick_list.author: Gumby and Sella Turcica
limerick_list.text:
On the stage, ballerinas chassé;
They plié, pirouette, and jeté.
But they'll never go far
Without time at the barre.
(It's for practice, not drinks, in ballet.)

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"The breaks that are labeled Missouri,"
Claimed Governor Jesse Ventura,
"Are a part of my turf.
They're a bugger to surf,
Taking loads of finesse and bravura."

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
So with me you expostulate. Tosh!
 Your attempts at dissuasion won't wash;
 They're discouraging words
 Only fit for the birds—
And my plans they're unlikely to quash!

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Shh! I've been in a death grip all year —
An extremely taut hold, caused by fear.
I was drunk when I picked her:
I wed a constrictor.
I'm a slave tightly clutched! "Nothing, dear".

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
A cache can hold valuables, trash,
Hidden ammo, or moonshiner's mash.
But in no way, I say,
Should you say it cachet—
Those who mix these two need a good smash.

limerick_list.author: Doug Harris
limerick_list.text:
His disciples were fishers of men.
Those they caught in their nets needed then
To have somewhere to grapple
With prayer, hence the chapel
Called bethel: God's house, say Amen!

limerick_list.author: Jonathan M. Guberman
limerick_list.text:
A student once queried his prof
If his head might inflate from a cough.
The prof uttered a curse;
His reply was quite terse:
"That's balloony!" he said with a scoff.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
This one's C7H7O,
And as chemical radicals go,
I find acrinyl tough
To make sense of, with stuff
Like hydroxy and benzyl in tow.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
Butterfingered habitual spiller
Left her not enough breakfast to fill her.
He's the clumsiest ox,
Knocking over the box:
Little brother, the cereal killer.

limerick_list.author: S. A. McBurnie
limerick_list.text:
In the wake of your wreck and its strife,
More bad news arrives, twisting the knife:
That old truck was your friend,
But it's come to the end
Of its absolute physical life.

limerick_list.author: Chuck Folkers
limerick_list.text:
The automatist's very emphatic
That our actions are all automatic.
But if he's correct
About cause-and-effect,
Then why's our behavior erratic?

limerick_list.author: John Critten
limerick_list.text:
It's not Epsom, I can't see a horse!
That's not baseball, it's soccer — what sauce!
On the racecourse a wicket,
Local sides playing cricket!
Is this Derby old hat? Well of course.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Disadvantage may cause people harm.
Cousin Margo has only one arm.
Though she hopes she can cope
When she skis down a slope,
Many bystanders gasp with alarm.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
All this stuff is the weirdest by far:
You can haggle for haggis or gar,
Buy a rug for a lark,
Or a two-headed shark,
Since this open-air market's bizarre.

limerick_list.author: mike scholtes
limerick_list.text:
I look 'round; the world's crap, and we're clods.
After carefully judging the odds
That the planet's land masses
Emerged from vast asses,
I worship incontinent gods.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
From dawn until dark he baled hay.
Then his boss said, "Don't worry, José —
I'll pay you tomorrow."
Alas, to his sorrow,
No way did José get back pay.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
Oh, you sisters are glowing today!
And those abdomens? Growing, I'd say.
Since you're pregnant, don't fail
To get up on this scale—
Now you're all in the family weigh!

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
Bake mom's dirt cake? A worthy ambition,
But "use Hydrox"? I call that sedition.
Here, where Oreo's king,
Why sub in second string?
Mom worked clean, Sis, beyond all suspicion.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
The president spoke with alarm
About cuts that, he said, would cause harm
So severe, but when that
Didn't work, he then sat
With his rivals and turned on the charm.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
I've acquired a new partner who's nifty:
She's experienced, honest and thrifty,
With both wisdom and wit.
All our profits we'll split—
The arrangement seems fit—fifty-fifty.

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
At the dance, lovely Fi Phelps is glad
That her dress (long red silk) means she's clad
Like a handful of rellies,
In ball gown and wellies—
It helps if you're barkingly mad!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
If it's straightened or swept with a broom,
That won't make it a bioclean room.
You should keep within reach
Disinfectants like bleach:
On bacteria, lower the boom!

limerick_list.author: lopey
limerick_list.text:
I'm rechecking some books that I've read
To determine what they might have said
On the future, and such.
I don't think on it much,
But my mom always said, "Plan ahead."

limerick_list.author: proof
limerick_list.text:
The deluge made a terrible flood
And the river churned banks into mud.
Then we came home to find
That our house, undermined,
With a splash in the river had slud.

limerick_list.author: DenmarK
limerick_list.text:
The Moon makes a heavenly glide.
Far along her ellipse she doth ride.
With the Earth at the focus,
She draws from her locus
The sea's apogean low tide.

limerick_list.author: Brian Cairns
limerick_list.text:
As we travelled the road to Beijing
(China's capital, once called Peking),
The roadsign displaying it
Gave no help in saying it—
A curious, picture-like thing.

limerick_list.author: ProfKlyve
limerick_list.text:
The term Chermidae now is passé;
It's a taxon that's not used today.
Need to ID a louse
On a plant in your house?
They're in Psyllidae now, where they'll stay.

limerick_list.author: speedysnail
limerick_list.text:
"I've invited you here on the hunch
That you're all a competitive bunch.
There's a lot on the table,
So let's, now we're able,
Get straight down to business." Munch, munch.

limerick_list.author: old dad
limerick_list.text:
An expositor's one who explains.
He expounds until no doubt remains.
So when asked: "Are you sure?"
My reaction's demure:
"No expositor, I — it takes brains."

limerick_list.author: JimInRoses
limerick_list.text:
Who deputes? Well, a deputator might.
Townsfolk trust that their sheriff is right.
Once, when raising a posse,
I deputised Flossie
As side-saddle deputy knight.

limerick_list.author: skipjordan
limerick_list.text:
My eyeglasses worked—but no more:
There's a blur where no blur was before.
Am I now going blind—
Maybe losing my mind?
Damn! Just stepped on my lens on the floor.

limerick_list.author: neilski
limerick_list.text:
Most bicycles purchased today
Have wheels equirotal. Don't pay
If one wheel is smaller;
You'll soon be a faller.
Penny-farthings? That look is passé.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Once you've dined here, you want to return.
A Black Forest location, we learn,
Culinarily seen,
Is what Bonn once had been.
Baiersbronn, for your cooking I yearn!

limerick_list.author: Jason Talbott
limerick_list.text:
I wanted to purchase a tuba
From a seller residing in Cuba.
I play a nice largo,
But the U.S. embargo
Has forced me to buy from Aruba.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
The word blow means "cocaine." That you know.
But in England it's weed that's called blow.
Fearing narcs? Watch your ass!
Do without coke and grass:
Get your high from a tasty Merlot.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
The gingery rootstock, galangal
Is why soto's a soup with an angle:
The root's also for farts,
Claims the herbalist's arts,
And there's more, but too much to untangle.

limerick_list.author: Dr. Work
limerick_list.text:
A new author burst forth on the scene,
And what's more, he was barely eighteen.
He came out of the blue
With a voice fresh and new—
Very soon, he was rolling in green…

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
The killers seize more and more land,
Yet our prez thinks we're crippling their brand.
What is obvious, he
Just pretends not to see
As he buries his head in the sand.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
In some peaches the fruit's tightly held
By a pit that can grasp like a weld.
Such a seed is a clinger,
Like a lover who'd linger
After having been firmly expelled.

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
This shrub bears an edible fruit
With a flavor of local repute.
It's a berry called "dingle,"
Dark red, and its zing'll
Surprise you—it's truly a beaut.

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
Ardent Romeo, keen to confess
Love for Juliet, surely could guess
That when fuelled by a feud,
Fighting might have ensued
And would end in their deaths. What a mess.

limerick_list.author: sigg
limerick_list.text:
Absolving was what he eschewed.
He was loud and abusive and rude.
"There'll be hell to pay
If I have my way!
And somebody's gonna get sued!"

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
There were half-empty bottles galore,
And their contents we went on to pour
Into one plastic bucket
On the beach of Nantucket
As a drink of all nations. Some more?

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
I don't get why a beautiful filly
Like you should need makeup.  It's silly.
Your bare face is enough.
You're already hot stuff,
So embellishment's gilding the lily.

limerick_list.author: BeefyNZ
limerick_list.text:
It's abembryonic, this spot
(It's one where the embryo's not).
Whilst forming a baby,
We find that there may be
Some places unfit for a tot!

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
The compartment was empty.  He saw
'Ladies Only' and silently swore.
Every seat there was spare—
But, forbidden in there
With his lady, he walked past the door.

limerick_list.author: Roger Dunn
limerick_list.text:
I imagine their voices I hear,
Coming home, straight from school. They'll appear,
Shouting, "Dad!"  There it stops.
Empty house. Penny drops.
I'm alone—been divorced for a year.

limerick_list.author: geniuswaitress
limerick_list.text:
"Oh waitress, please take back this wine.
It is corked, and it smells like a swine."
So I said: "Oh it does?
Well that's funny, because
Your first several glasses were fine."

limerick_list.author: Duncan Stevens
limerick_list.text:
Young Donald's maneuver was deft:
"No service for me! I'm bereft!
These spurs are a curse
On my feet—and, what's worse,
See this hangnail! Oh, darn, I'm 4-F'd."

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
From Texas to Hong Kong it's "ciao,"
For "hello," and "goodbye," and so, now,
My dismay I am quelling
At Italianate spelling
Of chow, though I can't say just how!

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
The world's highest summit is near,
And this Sherpa is chewing my ear,
Spewing maxims non-stop
As we trudge to the top.
Am I climbing Mount Aphorist here?

limerick_list.author: BobHale
limerick_list.text:
The extract they used from my book
Was lacking a suitable hook.
Thus a lukewarm review
Was the best they could do —
So nobody bought it to look.

limerick_list.author: Partypoet
limerick_list.text:
The lady seemed calm and serene
As the thug sauntered onto the scene.
She dealt him a blow!
(Well, how could he know
She'd a brown belt since she was sixteen?)

limerick_list.author: Tim Alborn
limerick_list.text:
Assertedly, Elvis is dead—
But according to something I read,
He's alive. Don't you trust
All those doubters; you must
Read the National Enquirer instead.

limerick_list.author: SusanL
limerick_list.text:
Our growth through this union's unceasable.
My people have always been peaceable.
Your friendship is sought,
With not one battle fought.
I believe our two clans are cohesible.

limerick_list.author: Janet McConnaughey
limerick_list.text:
He's gorgeous, his sumptuous array
All blue silk and green velvet. He'd say
He is greater than I,
But we'll both of us die
And rise naked upon the Last Day.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
When the captain announced, "Please don't panic,"
We were halfway across the Atlantic.
There was something amiss
So I told myself, "This
Is the last time I sail the Titanic!"

limerick_list.author: Val
limerick_list.text:
It's grown late and you've stayed in all day,
But the call centre says it's okay
And confirms that it's true
Your delivery's due,
Then assures you it is on its way.

limerick_list.author: PGS
limerick_list.text:
Sixty rpm's one cps.
Dear reader, I'm sure you can guess—
With r: "revolutions"—
For his contributions
One Hertz shall this unit express.

limerick_list.author: Carl Lands
limerick_list.text:
King Agrippa, on hearing Paul's plight,
Of his fight with the Jews, of the light
On the road to Damascus,
Said, "Paul, if you ask us,
We almost believe—but not quite."

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
Now Jill's married (Frank thinks this is rotten!),
See-through nighties are largely forgotten.
And what's taken the place
Of thin, delicate lace?
It's all thick adiaphanous cotton.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
"To disexercise dogs," Dan explained,
"Is to leave them completely untrained.
Or it could be like when
They are left in a pen,
Day and night, and severely restrained."

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
On Ms Singer's exam was a zinger:
"Please define this short phrase: chicken finger."
Every classmate sure knows
On their feet hens have toes—
It's a snack one might serve with a stinger.

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
She waved off the flavor you gave her,
Though you gave her her favorite flavor.
Fearing each ounce of fat,
She discountenanced that.
(She observed what you served with disfavor.)

limerick_list.author: StephenGold
limerick_list.text:
An unfortunate girl, named Colleen,
Had a head in the shape of a screen,
But this didn't deflect her—
She bought a projector;
Now she headlines in every scene.

limerick_list.author: Jason Talbott
limerick_list.text:
A convertible's roof that won't close
In a dust storm's the least of your woes.
If you're wearing a suit
Or an outfit that's cute,
A dust coat's the cure I'd propose.

limerick_list.author: SusanL and Michael Toalster
limerick_list.text:
She's old, and she's slow, so take care.
You can't sail her just any-old-where.
She made trading a breeze
All across the high seas—
But it's time to retire our crare.

limerick_list.author: Ritepath
limerick_list.text:
In the convent, the band's in despair:
Only one drum for two nuns to share.
Can you solve this conundrum?
(Yes, groan at the pun.) Drum
Up answers, or hear the nuns swear.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
"You're ready to enter the lists,"
Claims his wife but, averse, he resists.
When the witch tries to force him,
Says if not, she'll divorce him,
He unhitches the nag with his fists.

limerick_list.author: Atticus Vere
limerick_list.text:
When I'm at myself, man, I'm sublime:
Won't be bested when I'm in my prime.
No debate or delay—
Just get out of my way,
'Cause today I've got mountains to climb.

limerick_list.author: psh
limerick_list.text:
Now, contristate's considered passé —
A word of just slight use today.
It still means "to make sad,"
Oft for reasons so bad
Consolation won't take woe away.

limerick_list.author: Workshop
limerick_list.text:
To debilitate Drew I made stew
That I poisoned by adding some yew.
A devitalized spouse
Gave us run of the house;
Then his wife and I did what we do.

limerick_list.author: rusty
limerick_list.text:
In old York, a young jeweller, gay Clem,
Just adores frocking up, going fem.
How's he stick stones and pearls
On that skirt (it's a girl's)?
He (ahem) says, "By gum, I begem".

limerick_list.author: Kevin Dopart
limerick_list.text:
If you want to have fun you will find
That the Cat in the Hat is the kind
Of a book you should take,
But the Things in there make
A big mess that your mother would mind.

limerick_list.author: Aliza
limerick_list.text:
Since the angioid highways have spread
In a network to 'burbs where folks fled,
We return to our chores
In the cities' dense cores
Through clogged arteries, much to our dread.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A barmcloth is sensibly viewed
As a must when you're working with food.
I've often contended
It's well recommended
To men frying bacon while nude.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Down a blind lane, she said, "Do a u-ie.
It's a dead-ending byway!"  "Oh, phooey!
That map we bought lied;
Our new GPS fried,
And our compass? Gone south — acting screwy."

limerick_list.author: mephistopheles
limerick_list.text:
After Reeling and Writhing, Ambition
Could promote your instructional mission.
But Distraction soon after
Contemptuous laughter
Would Uglify, causing Derision."

limerick_list.author: Chaiwallah
limerick_list.text:
Fond of cashews, Dad choked on a nut,
Which had lodged in his throat, not his gut,
The doctor said, "Death—
Due to blockage of breath,
Anacardic, not cardiac, glut."

limerick_list.author: Mary
limerick_list.text:
"I require you to act more compliantly,"
Said the Pontifex Rex, self-reliantly.
His bearing resembled,
To the cave clan assembled,
A priest's, but they faced him defiantly.

limerick_list.author: Celia Warren
limerick_list.text:
The problem with nouveau cuisine
Is that plates arrive looking too clean
And I'm in the mood
For plentiful food:
Roast beef of old England, I mean.

limerick_list.author: Morphiend
limerick_list.text:
I'm playing a role when I greet you
In order to swindle and cheat you.
I'm a guy on the grift
If you're catching my drift—
If you're not, I'm delighted to meet you.

limerick_list.author: Richard Stehr
limerick_list.text:
Watching TV all day is my vice.
Couch potato they call me (not nice).
But if I were a man
Doing this in Japan,
Would I then be considered couch rice?

limerick_list.author: Bluebelle
limerick_list.text:
Lord Cut-Glass, who lives at The Gable,
Feels he's better and so much more able
Than proles from the slums,
Who feed on the crumbs
That fall from his classy glass table.

limerick_list.author: birdbarf
limerick_list.text:
Afrikaans is where blesbok's name came,
And the bontebok's nearly the same.
This antelope's rare,
Has spiral horns (pair),
And a blaze on its face, hence its name.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
A butner made buttons (that's it) —
Just the kind on your clothes, I submit.
But for buttons like those
To launch rockets, God knows,
These old workers were wholly unfit.

limerick_list.author: MikeAq
limerick_list.text:
Our teacher, the dismal Miss Dissel,
Insists that we learn this epistle —
Know by heart every page,
Else she gets in a rage
And refuses to signal dismissal.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
Seems that wheat is the basic material
In this food that, to me, is ethereal.
I first ate farina
In Herzegovina.
It's a delicate, mild-tasting cereal.

limerick_list.author: SheilaB
limerick_list.text:
In a storm, the dark night may be brightening
With wild streaks in the sky that are frightening.
Though it's hard to explain,
It's like links on a chain;
That makes plain the odd name—it's chain lightning.

limerick_list.author: David Franks
limerick_list.text:
He won't cry in his beer—that would be a
Deviation from habit.  You'll see a
Rum and lime drink instead
Where his river is shed.
It's a clear case of dacryorrhea.

limerick_list.author: Chris J. Strolin
limerick_list.text:
In her booth at the diner, she'd lie back
While seductively sending her pie back.
"Gal, you sure caught my eye!"
"So, you wanna get high?"
"No, not really. I just want my eye back."

limerick_list.author: Chris Doyle
limerick_list.text:
On the corner, a destitute man
Has a cup and a desperate plan.
It's a dismal ordeal
To be down at the heel
In a life that is cadge-as-cadge-can.

limerick_list.author: Carl Lands
limerick_list.text:
The arrow that Jonathan lobbed
Out to David went long: Saul was fobbed,
All his ill will confirmed;
The hobnobbers affirmed
Lasting love, and to Nob David hobbed.

limerick_list.author: FlippingMackerel
limerick_list.text:
Each person's got depth (I say "deepness"),
A measure of trueness... or cheapness.
An honest guy's "deep",
But I find if you leap
Into pits that are deep, you find steepness.

limerick_list.author: Kevin Lucas
limerick_list.text:
To a restaurant I went for Chinese,
Saw the placemat, and felt ill at ease.
I mistook what it features—
Their zodiac creatures.
"The menu," I asked, "includes these?"

text: This is a test to see how well you are paying attention. This text is a series of limericks. At the end of the list of limericks, there will be a question. The question will be about one of the limericks. Please answer the question as concisely as possible.
